BK Nephropathy (Option D): BK virus mainly affects renal transplant recipients or immunocompromised patients, leading to nephropathy and renal dysfunction, but it does not cause an aplastic crisis.

questions.question: A 25-year-old patient presents to the hospital with symptoms of hydrophobia, which is often associated with rabies infection. The clinician decides to perform further diagnostic tests on the patient's corneal scraping to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following tests is the most appropriate and accurate for confirming the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation: reaction (RT-PCR) is a highly sensitive and specific method for detecting viral RNA, including the RNA of the rabies virus. It can be used in various types of samples, including saliva, cerebrospinal fluid, skin biopsies, and corneal scrapings. It is therefore the most appropriate test for confirming a diagnosis of rabies. Incorrect Options: Option B - Viral culture: While viral culture can be used to diagnose many types of viral infections, it is not typically used for rabies due to the slow growth of the virus and the biohazard risk associated with culturing the rabies virus. Option C - Antibody detection by ELISA: ELISA (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) can be used to detect antibodies against the rabies virus in the patient's blood. However, it can take 1-2 weeks after the onset of symptoms for these antibodies to develop, so a negative result does not rule out rabies in the early stages of the disease. Option D - Direct fluorescent antibody test: This test is used to detect the presence of rabies virus in a sample (often a skin biopsy from the back of the neck) by staining it with fluorescent antibodies that bind to the virus. While it's a common method for diagnosing rabies, its sensitivity can be lower than RT-PCR, especially in corneal scrapings. Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology Apurba S Sastry, 3rd Edition, Pages 721

questions.question: A 13-year-old girl presents with fever and retro-orbital headache for 2 days. Her Tourniquet test and NS1 antigen are positive, suggesting Dengue infection. Which of the following findings qualifies as a severe dengue criterion?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) AST and ALT >1000 Explanation: Severe dengue (Dengue hemorrhagic fever grade III & IV / Dengue shock syndrome) criteria include: Severe plasma leakage → leading to shock or fluid accumulation (pleural effusion/ascites). Severe bleeding. Severe organ involvement: Liver: AST/ALT >1000 U/L (marker of severe hepatitis). CNS involvement: Encephalitis, seizures. Myocarditis, renal failure. Clinical presentation of Dengue: Uncategorised fever No typical features Break bone fever (Classical dengue fever/ acute viral infection) Retro orbital pain Arthralgia Severe myalgia and headache Bimodal presentation of fever: 39-40°C, peaks on days 1-2 Resurges: day 5-6 Recovery: day 7-10. Rash: pin-point eruptions on the face, neck and chest followed by maculopapular or scarlatiniform on 3rd or 4th day. Dengue haemorrhagic syndrome Dengue fever + hemorrhagic manifestations(bleeding from any orifice) Rash: Maculopapular/ Rubelliform Lab diagnosis 20% increase in hematocrit Thrombocytopenia (<1 lac) Clinical diagnosis Tourniquet test- >10 petechiae/ sq inch area Dengue shock syndrome Pulse pressure - <20 mmHg Mean systolic pressure - <90mmHg: adults, <80 mmHg: children. Dengue complications Neurological Dengue encephalopathy is most commonly encountered neurological complication of dengue virus linked primarily to dengue hemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome EEG may show abnormalities such as burst suppression and seizures CSF profiles typically remain normal. Neuroimaging can be normal or reveal diffuse cerebral edema. Encephalitis GBS Stroke Cardiomyopathy Dengue virus-induced dilated cardiomyopathy should always be considered if a dengue fever patient has refractory shock and signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure. Hepatic injury Liver involvement in dengue is a crucial feature The effect ranges from an asymptomatic rise in liver enzymes to the development of ALF The most common atypical manifestation reported was hepatitis Pneumonia Staphylococcus pneumonia is an important accompanying problem seen in dengue patient co-infection between dengue and influenza can result in exacerbation of pneumonia Orchitis Orchitis usually occurs together with epididymitis Commonly seen in men between 14 and 35 years of age. Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever All of the following: Acute onset of fever 2-7 days duration Hemorrhagic manifestations Positive tourniquet test/Petechiae Ecchymosis Purpura/Bleeding from mucosa, GIT, Injection sites, etc Platelet count ≤ 100,000 cells/cu.mm. Plasma leakage Rising hematocrit Hemoconcentration >20% Pleural effusion, ascites/Hypoproteinemia) Dengue Shock Syndrome DHF criteria plus Signs of Shock Tachycardia/Cool extremities/Weak pulse/Lethargy/Restlessness Pulse pressure <20 mm Hg with increased Diastolic pressure (e.g. 100/80) Hypotension (Systolic <80 mm Hg for age <5 years/80-90 mm Hg for older children and adults) Leucopenia plus thrombocytopenia (Option A): Thrombocytopenia (<100,000/mm³) and leucopenia are common findings in dengue fever, but they do not indicate severe dengue unless associated with bleeding, shock, or organ involvement. Persistent vomiting (Option B): It is a warning sign for dengue progression, but alone does not classify as severe dengue. Hepatomegaly >1 cm (Option C): Mild hepatomegaly is

questions.question: An 18-day-old baby presents with fever and cough. On examination, vesicles are observed over the trunk and upper limb. The mother had genital ulcers one year ago, which have since resolved. Biopsy of the vesicles reveals multinucleated giant cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Herpes simplex virus (HSV) Explanation: Neonatal HSV infection typically results from vertical transmission during vaginal delivery, especially if the mother had genital HSV infection. The presence of vesicles in a newborn with a maternal history of genital ulcers strongly suggests neonatal herpes simplex infection. Microscopic features Tzanck smear: Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained 'ground-glass' chromatin ( Tzanck cells ). Formation of Lipschutz bodies (Cowdry type A). Molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV) (Option B): MCV causes pearly, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication, not vesicles. Human papillomavirus (HPV) (Option C): HPV is associated with warts, not vesicular lesions. Varicella (Option D) : Varicella (chickenpox) also causes vesicular rash, but it is less likely in a neonate unless there is maternal varicella exposure close to delivery. Multinucleated giant cells can be seen in both HSV and VZV, but maternal history of genital ulcers favors HSV over varicella. Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page 476, 480, 482.

questions.question: A patient with HIV presents with white patches on the tongue and buccal mucosa. These patches cannot be removed by scraping. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Epstein-Barr Virus Explanation: Oral Hairy Leukoplakia is caused by EBV and is strongly associated with HIV/AIDS. It presents as painless, white, corrugated patches on the lateral borders of the tongue and sometimes on the buccal mucosa. Unlike oral candidiasis, these lesions cannot be scraped off. Candida (Option B): Oral candidiasis (thrush) is common in HIV, but the white plaques can be scraped off, leaving an erythematous base. Confirmed with potassium hydroxide (KOH) prep, showing budding yeast and pseudohyphae. HSV (Option C): HSV causes painful vesicles or ulcers rather than white plaques. HHV-8 (Option D): HHV-8 is associated with Kaposi sarcoma, which presents as vascular, reddish-purple nodules, not white plaques Reference: Apurba S Sastry- Essentials Of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 583, 552 Jawetz, Melnick, & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 28th Edition, Pages 702, 704 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK526126/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560911/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK442013/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482197/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK556023/

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of diseases and their corresponding populations related to parvovirus is incorrect? 1. Aplastic crises in sickle cell disease 2. Viral envelop - Naked virus 3. Erythema infectiosum - infants 4. Non-erosive arthritis - Patients of SLE
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 4 Explanation: leading to the characteristic rash. Clinical Manifestations of Parvovirus infections: Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease) Children: "Slapped cheek" facial rash. Adult women: Symmetrical polyarthropathy, often in hand and knee joints. Transient Aplastic Crisis : Severe acute anemia in patients with pre-existing hemolytic anemia. Pure Red Cell Aplasia : Chronic anemia in immunocompromised individuals due to persistent B19 infection. Non-Immune Hydrops Fetalis : Fatal fetal anemia and death; occurs via transplacental transmission (30% of cases) Highest risk in the second trimester. Papular-Purpuric Gloves and Socks Syndrome : Painful, itchy, and symmetric swelling and erythema of distal hands and feet; may mimic acute meningococcemia. Laboratory Diagnosis PCR : Highly sensitive, detects viral DNA (VP1, VP2 genes) in serum, tissue, or respiratory secretions. ELISA : Detects IgM antibody (early indicator, elevated 2–3 months) and IgG against VP1 and VP2 antigens. Immunohistochemistry : Detects viral antigens in fetal tissues and bone marrow. Bone marrow cytology shows Giant pro-erythroblasts with multiple cytoplasmic projections that look like "dog ears" or "pseudopodia" .

questions.question: Vaccination against which of the following is recommended in the elderly? 1. Varicella zoster virus 2. Rota virus 3. Influenza vaccine 4. Pneumococcal Meningitis
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 1, 3, and 4 Explanation: Vaccination against varicella zoster virus is recommended as latent VZV Infection can reactivate as herpes zoster or shingles. As age advances, cell-mediated immune responses (CMI) to VZV decline, with resultant increased incidence of reactivation as herpes zoster among older people. The Influenza vaccine is highly recommended in the elderly to prevent severe disease. Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPV) is given to people aged 65 and over. It helps prevent meningitis and other illnesses caused by 23 strains of pneumococcal bacteria Vaccination recommended in elderly are: Pneumococcal vaccine Influenza vaccine Varicella zoster vaccine Covid 19 vaccine Td vaccine Reference: pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10537287/

questions.question: What is the causative organism?
questions.explanation: I (coccobacillary) rod. Aerosol transmission. Nontypeable (unencapsulated) strains are the most common cause of mucosal infections (otitis media, conjunctivitis, bronchitis) as well as invasive infections since the vaccine for capsular type b was introduced. Produces IgA protease. Culture on chocolate agar, which contains factors V (NAD+ ) and X (hematin) for growth; can also be grown with S aureus , which provides factor V via RBC hemolysis. Ha emop hilus causes e piglottitis (endoscopic appearance ) , can be “cherry red” in children; “thumb sign” on lateral neck x-ray ), m eningitis, o titis media, and p neumonia. Incorrect Options: Option A - Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV): This option is incorrect Option C - Parainfluenza virus: This option is incorrect Option D - Newcastle disease virus: This option is incorrect Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: If a patient's plasma contains elevated levels of interferon beta, it is indicative of a probable infection caused by-
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Virus Explanation: Interferon beta (IFN- β ) is produced by fibroblasts in response to viral infections, particularly when the body detects the presence of viral RNA or other viral components. Elevated levels of IFN- β are typically indicative of a viral infection because it plays a role in the innate immune response, helping to limit viral replication. Interferons (IFNs): Types : IFN- α : Produced by macrophages, has antiviral action. IFN- β : Produced by fibroblasts, also has antiviral action. IFN- γ : Produced by T helper cells, does not have antiviral action but plays a role in cell-mediated immunity (CMI). Mechanism of Action : IFNs do not directly act on viruses but stimulate host cells to produce proteins that inhibit protein synthesis and viral replication. Innate Immunity : IFNs are part of innate immunity, nonspecific, and produced quickly after infection (within hours). Unlike antibodies, they don’t have immunological memory. Inducers : IFN production is triggered by agents like RNA viruses (e.g., togaviruses, vesicular stomatitis virus), double-stranded RNA, bacterial endotoxin, and synthetic polymers. Preparations : Human IFNs : Prepared via DNA recombinant technology. Pegylated IFNs : IFN- α linked to polyethylene glycol, resulting in slower absorption, decreased clearance, and more sustained serum levels. Administered once a week. Clinical Applications : Topical : Used for rhinovirus infections, genital warts, and herpetic keratitis. Systemic : Used for chronic hepatitis B, C, and D infections. Antiproliferative Action : Used to treat cancers (e.g., hairy cell leukemia, Kaposi’s sarcoma) and autoimmune diseases (e.g., multiple sclerosis). Bacteria (Option B), Fungi (Option C), and Mycoplasma (Option D) : While infections caused by these pathogens may also trigger immune responses, they typically don't induce the production of interferon beta in the same way viruses do. Instead, bacterial infections often activate other components of the immune system, such as neutrophils and macrophages, and induce the release of cytokines like interleukin-1 or tumor necrosis factor (TNF), rather than IFN- β . Reference: Apurba S Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 93

questions.question: Which of the following viral infections has the least teratogenicity?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Herpes Simplex Virus-2 Explanation: Herpes Simplex Virus-2 rarely causes congenital malformations. Neonatal herpes is usually acquired perinatally during vaginal delivery, leading to skin, eye, and mouth (SEM) disease, encephalitis, or disseminated disease, but not congenital structural defects. Not a significant teratogen compared to CMV, rubella, or varicella. TORCH infections include toxoplasmosis, rubella, CMV, Herpes and HIV. Vertical transmission of diseases. 1st trimester Rubella, Chickenpox/varicella 2nd trimester Parvovirus 3rd trimester Toxoplasmosis, CMV, Hepatitis B and Syphilis. During delivery HIV and herpes Infection Pathogen & Transmission Clinical Features Toxoplasmosis Toxoplasma gondii (transplacental from infected mother, cat feces, undercooked meat) Classic triad: chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications; anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, seizures, intellectual disability Varicella (Option B ruled out) Varicella-zoster virus (aerosols, direct contact, transplacental) Congenital varicella syndrome: skin lesions, limb hypoplasia, neurodevelopmental delay Syphilis Treponema pallidum (sexual transmission, transplacental, peripartum) Stillbirth, Hutchinson triad (notched teeth, interstitial keratitis, deafness), skeletal abnormalities Parvovirus B19 Parvovirus B19 (respiratory droplets, transplacental) Hydrops fetalis, neurodevelopmental defects, fetal anemia Rubella (Option D ruled out) Rubella virus (respiratory droplets, transplacental) Congenital rubella syndrome: sensorineural deafness, cataracts, congenital heart disease, hepatosplenomegaly Cytomegalovirus (CMV) (Option A ruled out) CMV (body fluids, blood transfusion, organ transplant, transplacental, peripartum, breast milk) Leading cause of non-genetic congenital hearing loss, petechiae, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, neurodevelopmental deficits Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV-1 & HSV-2) HSV (direct contact, mucosal exposure, peripartum) Neonatal herpes: vesicular rash, encephalitis, seizures, bulging fontanelle, viral sepsis, organ failure Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK545148/ Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 105

questions.question: A patient presented with high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures. He was diagnosed with HSV encephalitis. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis?

options.D: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) CSF PCR for viral DNA Explanation: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for HSV DNA in CSF is the gold standard for diagnosing HSV encephalitis due to its high sensitivity and specificity. HSV Encephalitis Herpesviruses: Large, double-stranded DNA viruses; 8 types affect humans (HHV-1 to HHV-8). HSV Types: HSV-1: Most common in adults & children; sporadic, non-seasonal. HSV-2: More common in neonates & immunocompromised individuals. Etiology Causative Agents: HSV-1 (90%), HSV-2 (10%). Structure: Enveloped, icosahedral, double-stranded DNA virus. Host Cell Entry: Via nectin-1 and HVEM receptors on neurons. Pathogenesis: Primary infection: HSV infects skin/mucosa, enters neurons, and travels retrogradely to ganglia. Latency: Controlled by immune mechanisms (histone deposition, cytokines). Reactivation: Can spread to CNS via trigeminal or olfactory nerves. Pathophysiology Transmission: Close contact; HSV-1 → oral, HSV-2 → genital. Brain Invasion Routes: Oropharyngeal infection → Trigeminal/Olfactory nerve spread. Reactivation in ganglia → CNS spread. Latent HSV in the brain reactivates. Affected Areas: Temporal lobes, limbic system → hemorrhagic necrosis. Immunosuppression Risks: Natalizumab, TNF- α inhibitors, whole-brain radiation. Clinical Presentation Prodrome: Fever, malaise, headache, nausea. Typical Features: CNS signs: Confusion, seizures, focal deficits, personality changes. Behavioral syndromes: Hypomania, Klüver-Bucy, amnesia. Other findings: Incontinence, dermatomal rash, Guillain-Barré syndrome. Neonatal HSE: Presents at 1–3 weeks with irritability, lethargy, poor feeding, tremors, seizures. Herpetic skin lesions, thrombocytopenia, liver dysfunction may be present. Immunocompromised Patients: Atypical/subtle presentation, fewer focal deficits. Histopathology Gross Findings: Hemorrhagic necrosis in medial temporal and inferior frontal lobes. Microscopic Findings: Early: Neuronal ischemia, capillary dilation. Cowdry type A inclusions: Eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions in neurons. Late (>3 weeks): Necrosis, gliosis, inflammation. Atypical in Immunocompromised: Less inflammation, persistent viral antigens. Evaluation CSF Analysis (Gold Standard): ↑ WBCs (lymphocytic pleocytosis), ↑ protein, normal glucose. HSV PCR: 96% sensitive, 99% specific. Repeat PCR if negative within 72 hours in high-suspicion cases. HSV IgM in CSF is useful if PCR is unavailable or delayed. Imaging: CT: Initial test; may be normal early, later shows hypodensities, hemorrhage. MRI (Best Test): Temporal lobe hyperintensities on T2/FLAIR, sparing basal ganglia. Other Tests: CBC, metabolic panel. HSV PCR in blood useful in neonates & immunocompromised. Incorrect Options: IgM in CSF (Option A): IgM detection is not reliable for diagnosing HSV encephalitis because antibody production is delayed, and false negatives are common in early infection. Tzanck smear of CSF (Option B): Tzanck smear is used for HSV skin and mucosal lesions but is not useful for diagnosing CNS infections. It detects multinucleated giant cells, which are not seen in CSF. CSF culture on chick embryo lines (Option D): HSV culture requires human cell lines (not chick embryos), and CSF cultures are rarely positive in encephalitis. Culture is not a reliable diagnostic method for CNS infections.

questions.question: Which of the following laboratory tests is used to diagnose rotavirus diarrhea?

options.A: Antigen detection in the stool sample

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Antigen detection in the stool sample Explanation: Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) and latex agglutination tests are commonly used to detect rotavirus antigen (VP6 protein) in stool samples. This is the most sensitive and specific test for diagnosing rotavirus infection. Sandwich ELISA Procedure: Coating : Coat microtiter wells with goat anti-rotavirus antibody; add sample and incubate (overnight at 4°C or 2 hours at 37°C). Detection Antibody : Add enzyme-labelled anti-rotavirus antibody (e.g., with alkaline phosphatase) and incubate. Substrate Addition : Add para-nitrophenyl phosphate; enzyme activity causes colour change if rotavirus is present. Interpretation : Yellow colour development confirms a positive test; the ELISA reader provides quantitative colour readings. Incorrect Options: Antigen detection in blood (Option B): Rotavirus primarily affects the gastrointestinal tract and does not cause significant viremia; therefore, detecting antigens in blood is not a standard diagnostic method. Antibody detection in serum (Option C): While serology can detect past exposure to rotavirus, it is not useful for acute diagnosis, as antibodies appear later in the infection. Light microscopy of stool specimen (Option D): Routine light microscopy does not detect rotavirus, as the virus is too small to be seen. However, electron microscopy can visualize viral particles but is not routinely used due to cost and expertise requirements.

questions.question: A child presents with fever and rash. Urine examination shows cells with an "owl-eye" appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Cytomegalovirus Explanation: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is associated with "owl-eye" intranuclear inclusions in infected cells, which are enlarged and found in urine, blood, or tissue biopsy. In neonates, congenital CMV can present with jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, and petechial rash. In immunocompromised patients, CMV can cause retinitis, pneumonitis, and colitis. Cytomegalovirus General Characteristics Herpesvirus (HHV-5) , widespread prevalence. Often asymptomatic in healthy individuals but severe in immunocompromised and congenital infections. Remains latent post-infection and may reactivate . Linked to mucoepidermoid carcinoma and possibly prostate cancer . Transmission: Blood transfusions, organ transplantation, breastfeeding, close contact, perinatal, and sexual routes . Reactivation occurs in immunocompromised individuals, increasing morbidity and mortality . Pathophysiology Persists in myeloid cells , reactivates with immune suppression . Controlled mainly by cytotoxic T-cell immunity . Lifelong immune burden , affecting T-cell surveillance . Clinical Manifestations Immunocompetent patients: Often asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like syndrome (fever, rash, leukocytosis). Immunocompromised patients: Can cause severe organ-specific disease : CMV hepatitis → Risk of fulminant liver failure CMV retinitis → “ Pizza pie ” fundoscopic appearance CMV esophagitis, colitis, pneumonitis, polyradiculopathy, encephalitis, transverse myelitis Diagnosis Quantitative PCR : Preferred for viral detection. Histopathology (CMV inclusion bodies): Gold standard. Serology: Used for pre-transplant risk assessment but not for acute infection diagnosis . CMV-negative blood transfusions reserved for neonates and immunocompromised patients. Ganciclovir resistance testing is routine in transplant centers. Management Immunocompetent patients: Self-limiting, only symptomatic treatment required. Immunocompromised & severe cases: Require antivirals (ganciclovir, valganciclovir, foscarnet, cidofovir) . Prophylaxis: CMV-negative recipients of CMV-positive organ transplants should receive valganciclovir or ganciclovir with serological monitoring . Antiviral toxicity must be weighed against benefits. Incorrect Options: Epstein-Barr virus (Option B): Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) causes infectious mononucleosis, which presents with fever, pharyngitis, and lymphadenopathy. It is associated with atypical lymphocytes in blood smear, but not "owl-eye" inclusions in urine. Herpes simplex virus (Option C): Herpes simplex virus (HSV) causes painful vesicular lesions in the oral or genital region. It shows multinucleated giant cells with Cowdry type A inclusions on Tzanck smear, but not "owl-eye" inclusions. Toxoplasma gondii (Option D): Toxoplasma gondii causes congenital toxoplasmosis, which presents with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications. It is a protozoan, and its cysts do not show "owl-eye" inclusions. Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28089555/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK459185/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482197/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK563286/

questions.question: A patient hailing from Delhi presents with high fever, arthralgia, retrobulbar pain, and extensive petechial rash for 3 days. Lab investigations reveal: Hemoglobin: 9 g/dL WBC count: 9000 cells/mm³ Platelet count: 20,000 cells/mm³ Positive tourniquet test What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Dengue hemorrhagic fever Explanation: Dengue hemorrhagic fever is characterized by high fever, thrombocytopenia (<100,000/mm³), plasma leakage (leading to hemoconcentration, pleural effusion, or ascites), and hemorrhagic manifestations (petechiae, gum bleeding, or positive tourniquet test). The patient’s low platelet count (20,000/mm³) and petechiae confirm this diagnosis. Dengue complications Neurological Dengue encephalopathy is most commonly encountered neurological complication of dengue virus Linked primarily to dengue hemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome EEG may show abnormalities such as burst suppression and seizures CSF profiles typically remain normal. Neuroimaging can be normal or reveal diffuse cerebral edema. Encephalitis GBS Stroke Cardiomyopathy Dengue virus-induced dilated cardiomyopathy should always be considered if a dengue fever patient has refractory shock and signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure. Hepatic injury Liver involvement in dengue is a crucial feature The effect ranges from an asymptomatic rise in liver enzymes to the development of ALF The most common atypical manifestation reported was hepatitis Pneumonia Staphylococcus pneumonia is an important accompanying problem seen in dengue patient Co-infection between dengue and influenza can result in exacerbation of pneumonia Orchitis Orchitis usually occurs together with epididymitis Commonly seen in men between 14 and 35 years of age. Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever All of the following: Acute onset of fever 2-7 days duration Hemorrhagic manifestations Positive tourniquet test/Petechiae Ecchymosis Purpura/Bleeding from mucosa, GIT, Injection sites, etc Platelet count ≤ 100,000 cells/cu.mm. Plasma leakage Rising hematocrit Hemoconcentration >20% Pleural effusion, ascites/Hypoproteinemia) Dengue Shock Syndrome DHF criteria plus Signs of Shock Tachycardia/Cool extremities/Weak pulse/Lethargy/Restlessness Pulse pressure <20 mm Hg with increased Diastolic pressure (e.g. 100/80) Hypotension (Systolic <80 mm Hg for age <5 years/80-90 mm Hg for older children and adults) Incorrect Options: Dengue fever (Option A): Classical dengue fever presents with fever, arthralgia, myalgia, retro-orbital pain, and rash but does not involve significant thrombocytopenia (<100,000/mm³) or plasma leakage. The presence of petechiae and a positive tourniquet test suggests progression to Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever (DHF). Dengue shock syndrome (Option C): Dengue shock syndrome is a severe complication of DHF, with hypotension, circulatory collapse, and organ failure. The absence of shock symptoms (low BP, tachycardia, cold extremities, altered sensorium) rules out DSS. Malaria (Option D): Malaria presents with cyclic fevers, chills, sweating, and anemia. While severe Plasmodium falciparum infection can cause thrombocytopenia, petechial rash and a positive tourniquet test are not typical findings. Reference: Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 243 https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11910-022-01213-7 https://journals.lww.com/annals-of-medicine-and-sur

questions.question: Which of the following viruses are required to undergo reverse transcription for PCR?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) RSV Explanation: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is an RNA virus belonging to the Paramyxoviridae family. Since PCR typically amplifies DNA, reverse transcription is required to convert the viral RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA) before PCR can proceed. EBV (Option B): Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is a DNA virus belonging to the Herpesviridae family. As a DNA virus, it does not require reverse transcription for PCR. CMV (Option C): Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is another Herpesviridae family member and a DNA virus. PCR can directly amplify its DNA, so reverse transcription is unnecessary. Adenovirus (Option D): Adenoviruses are non-enveloped DNA viruses. Like other DNA viruses, they do not require reverse transcription for PCR. Reference: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0166093411004496 https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC120281/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK559285/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK459185/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK559072/

questions.question: A patient presented with a 3-day history of fever. Complete blood count (CBC) showed a platelet count of <90,000. For a suspicion of dengue, which of the following cannot be done on day 3 of infection?

options.D: Xenodiagnosis using culture in Aedes mosquito

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) IgM ELISA Explanation: Dengue-specific IgM antibodies typically appear around day 4 of illness. Diagnostic criteria: Fever: Must be present. Any 2 of the following 6 features: Retroorbital pain, myalgia, or "break-bone fever" Protracted nausea or vomiting: Can lead to dehydration Rash: Observed during the illness Warning signs: Any 1 positive sign (e.g., severe abdominal pain, persistent vomiting) Positive tourniquet test: >20 petechiae per square inch BP cuff inflated between systolic and diastolic blood pressure The cuff inflated for 5 minutes Leucopenia: Decreased white blood cell count Investigations Test Type Description ELISA IgM dengue virus (MAC-ELISA) Positive by Day 4 of infection Indicates recent infection NAAT Detects viral RNA Useful for early diagnosis NS-1 Antigen (Option B ruled out) NS-1 (IgG) Positive on Day 1 of infection Should be performed within 7 days of symptom onset PCR (Option A): Reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) is used to detect dengue viral RNA and is highly sensitive in the early phase of infection, typically within the first 5 days. It is useful for confirming the diagnosis in the acute stage. Xenodiagnosis using culture in Aedes mosquito (Option D): Xenodiagnosis involves infecting mosquitoes with a patient’s blood to detect the virus. While not a standard clinical diagnostic method, it theoretically could be performed on day 3. However, its practical use is limited to research settings rather than routine diagnosis. Reference: Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 244 https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC1876169/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5967223/

questions.question: The HIV genome requires which of the following to initiate the process of entering the host cell membrane?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) GP120 Explanation: GP120 (Glycoprotein 120) is the first viral protein involved in HIV entry. It binds to the CD4 receptor on host T-helper cells (CD4+ cells). After binding to CD4, GP120 undergoes a conformational change, allowing it to interact with co-receptors (CCR5 or CXCR4), facilitating viral entry. HIV is a spherical virus and its capsid has an icosahedral symmetry and also contains two copies of single-stranded positive-sense RNA in its core. Structure of HIV HIV is a spherical virus measuring 80–110 nm in diameter and belongs to the lentivirus family. Its structure includes: Envelope: Composed of: Lipid Component: Derived from the host cell membrane. Protein Component: gp120 : Glycoprotein forming knob-like spikes on the surface. gp41 : Glycoprotein that acts as anchoring transmembrane pedicles. (Option C ruled out) Nucleocapsid: The capsid has an icosahedral symmetry and contains core proteins. Inside, there is a dense cylindrical inner core that houses: RNA : Two identical copies of single-stranded positive-sense linear RNA. Viral Enzymes : Including reverse transcriptase, integrase, and proteases, which are closely associated with the RNA. HIV Serotyping Serotypes : HIV is classified into two main serotypes: HIV-1 and HIV-2. HIV-1 Groups : Divided into groups M, N, O, and a proposed group P. Group M : Dominant globally with eleven subtypes (A-K) and circulating recombinant forms (CRFs). Quasispecies : Hosts may have multiple closely related viral subtypes or CRFs. Geographical Distribution : Subtype A: Common in West Africa. Subtype B: Predominant in Europe, America, Japan, and Australia. Subtype C: Most common worldwide (47%); dominant in Southern/Eastern Africa, India, and China. Cameroon: High diversity and possible origin of the virus. Transmission : Subtypes C and E are more often transmitted heterosexually. Subtype B spreads primarily through blood and homosexual contact. HIV-2: Comprises eight subtypes (A–H), mainly found in Africa and parts of India, with Group A being the most common. CCR5 (Option B) & CXCR4 (Option D): Co-receptors needed after GP120 binding. CCR5 → Used by R5-tropic HIV strains (mostly during early infection). CXCR4 → Used by X4-tropic HIV strains (seen in later stages, more aggressive

questions.question: During the period between 1 to 4 months following renal transplantation, which pathogen is most commonly responsible for infecting renal transplant recipients?
questions.explanation: infect renal (solid organ) transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following transplantation because of reactivation of the virus in immunocompromised individuals. The immunosuppressive medications taken by transplant recipients increase their susceptibility to CMV infection, which can lead to significant morbidity and complications in the early post-transplant period. It presents in various forms, such as: Bilateral interstitial pneumonia, a life-threatening complication seen in 15–20% of bone marrow and solid organ transplant recipients Febrile leukopenia is seen among solid organ transplant recipients. Obliterative bronchiolitis in lung transplants. Graft atherosclerosis in heart transplants. Rejection of renal allografts. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect. They are not the most common organism to cause infection in an organ transplant recipient between 1 to 4 months. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: What is the term used to refer to the antigen known as Australia antigen among the options provided?
questions.explanation: represented by the HBsAg. The presence of HBsAg in the blood indicates an active Hepatitis B infection. It is an important marker used for screening and diagnosis of Hepatitis B. Structural proteins of HBV Description P – DNA Polymerase Largest Reverse transcriptase RNAse C – Core gene Has a core area and a pre-core area Core area coats for C antigen Pre-core area codes for E antigen S – Surface Antigen (Australia Antigen) These have different sizes (Small, medium and large) X – HBX responsible for carcinogenesis Liver (Hepatocellular carcinoma) Incorrect Options: Option B - HBeAg: HBeAg is another antigen produced by the Hepatitis B virus during active viral replication. Its presence indicates high viral replication and infectivity. HBeAg is used as a marker to assess the severity and prognosis of Hepatitis B infection. Option C - HBcAg: Hepatitis B core antigen (HBcAg) is an antigen that is located in the inner core of the Hepatitis B virus. Option D- HBX: HBX is an oncoprotein responsible for hepatocellular carcinoma. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following statements about Corona virus is incorrect?

options.C: Host cell entry occurs by attachment of viral spike
options.D: Human corona virus 229 E is alpha type

questions.explanation: A - ssRNA genome: Coronavirus is a single-stranded RNA virus. All RNA viruses have ssRNA genomes except Reoviridae (dsRNA) Option C - Host cell entry occurs by attachment of viral spike: Spreads primarily through respiratory droplets and aerosols. Host cell entry occurs by attachment of viral spike protein to angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 receptor on cell membranes. Option D - Human coronavirus 229E is an alpha-type: Human coronavirus 229E is indeed classified as an alpha-type coronavirus. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following virus is from Herpes virus family ?
questions.explanation: (HHV-4), is a member of the Herpesviridae family. It is associated with infectious mononucleosis (glandular fever) and is also linked to several other diseases, including certain cancers, such as Burkitt's lymphoma and nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Other members of Herpesviridae are Type Virus Associated Diseases HHV1 Herpes Simplex Virus 1 Oral herpes (cold sores), genital herpes, and encephalitis. HHV2 Herpes Simplex Virus 2 Genital herpes. HHV3 Herpes Zoster Virus Chickenpox and shingles. HHV4 Epstein–Barr virus Infectious mononucleosis, Burkitt's lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma. HHV5 Cytomegalovirus (largest member) Congenital infections, mononucleosis, organ transplant complications. HHV6 Human Herpesvirus 6 Roseola infantum, febrile illness HHV7 Human Herpesvirus 7 Febrile illness and a few cases of roseola infantum HHV8 Human Herpesvirus 8 Kaposi's sarcoma Incorrect Options: Option A - Rubella: Rubella is caused by the Rubella virus, which belongs to the Togaviridae family, not the Herpesviridae family. Option B - Measles: Measles, also known as rubeola, is caused by the Measles virus, which belongs to the Paramyxoviridae family. Option C - Rabies: Rabies is caused by the Rabies virus, which belongs to the Rhabdoviridae family. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following investigative procedures does not require the use of real-time PCR to determine viral load ?

options.A: Person with hepatitis B on tenofovir therapy
options.B: Detection of HSV causing temporal encephalitis
options.C: BK virus in patient of allograft renal transplant
options.D: CMV in patient of liver transplant

questions.explanation: quantification, hence real-time PCR is not preferred for detection of HSV causing temporal encephalitis, instead conventional PCR is preferred for the detection of the HSV DNA in cerebrospinal fluid. It can also differentiate between HSV 1 and HSV 2. Monitoring viral load is not routinely performed. Incorrect Options: Option A - Person with Hepatitis B on Tenofovir Therapy: In individuals with hepatitis B receiving tenofovir therapy, monitoring the viral load using real-time PCR is essential. It helps determine the response to treatment, assess viral suppression, and evaluate the risk of drug resistance. Option C - BK Virus in a Patient with Allograft Renal Transplant: BK virus infection can occur in patients who have undergone renal transplantation. Monitoring the viral load using real-time PCR in urine or blood samples is important to detect and manage BK virus-associated complications, such as nephropathy. Option D - CMV in a Patient with Liver Transplant: Cytomegalovirus infection is a significant concern in patients undergone solid organ transplantation. Real-time PCR for CMV viral load in blood is commonly performed in these patients to monitor for active infection, guide antiviral therapy, and assess response to treatment. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Vaccine that require strain change due to evolving organism is?
questions.explanation: undergo frequent genetic changes through antigenic drift (seen in influenza A & B, point mutation occurs) and antigenic shift (seen in Influenza A, genetic reassotment occurs) . This means that the viral strains circulating in the population can change over time, making the previously developed vaccines less effective against the new strains. Therefore, annual updates and strain changes are required in the influenza vaccine to ensure its effectiveness against the evolving strains. Incorrect Options: Option B - Diphtheria: The diphtheria vaccine is based on the toxoid produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae and does not require frequent strain changes. Option C - Polio: The polio vaccine targets the poliovirus, and while there are different serotypes of the virus, the vaccine does not require frequent strain changes as the available vaccines offer protection against all known serotypes. Option D - Typhoid : The typhoid vaccine is based on specific strains of Salmonella typhi bacteria and does not require frequent strain changes. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A 45-year-old male who had a history of domestic animal bite has come for a follow-up post 90 days after receiving rabies post-exposure prophylaxis. Now what will you use for rapid diagnosis of rabies in this case?

options.A: Skin biopsy with fluorescent antibody testing

questions.explanation: detection via direct fluorescent antibody testing is a commonly used method for rapid diagnosis of rabies. A skin biopsy sample taken from the nape of the neck with at least 10 hair follicles is the best specimen, and it is stained with fluorescent antibodies specific to the rabies virus. If the virus is present, it will bind to the antibodies and produce a fluorescence, confirming the diagnosis of rabies. Incorrect Options: Option B - Rabies Virus Specific Antibodies: Testing for rabies virus-specific antibodies in the patient's blood is not a suitable method for diagnosis of rabies. The presence of antibodies in blood appears late and is present in both rabies-infected and immunized individuals. CSF antibodies appear early, and they are produced only in rabies-infected individuals but not in response to vaccination Option C - Inoculation in Mice: Inoculation in mice helps in the isolation of the virus. It involves injecting the patient's tissue sample into a live mouse and observing for signs of rabies infection in the mouse. This method is time-consuming and may not provide rapid results. Option D - Corneal Impression Smear: Corneal impression smear is another method used for diagnosing rabies via direct fluorescent antibody testing, but with a low sensitivity of 30%. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which subtype of human papilloma virus has maximum chances of causing carcinoma cervix?
questions.explanation: HPV 16 and HPV 18, are known to have the highest association with the development of cervical carcinoma. Other high-risk human papillomaviruses associated with cervical carcinoma are HPV 31, 33, and 35. Incorrect Options: Option B - HPV 6 & 11: HPV 6 and HPV 11 are classified as low-risk subtypes and are commonly associated with condyloma acuminatum and laryngeal papillomatosis. Option C - HPV 31 & 32: HPV 31 is a high-risk subtype associated with cervical cancer, but HPV 32 is not associated with cervical carcinoma. Option D - HPV 1 & 2: HPV 1 and HPV 2 are low-risk subtypes associated with plantar warts/verruca and filiform warts. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A patient is diagnosed with Hepatitis B infection . Which of the following markers will always be present in his serum, even during recurrences, or if he develops chronic hepatitis?
questions.explanation: present during and after the acute phase of Hepatitis B infection. It persists in the serum even during recurrences and in individuals with chronic hepatitis. Incorrect Options: Option A - HBc Ag: Hepatitis B core antigen is not detectable in the serum. Option B - Anti HBs Ab: Antibodies against Hepatitis B surface antigen indicates immunity to Hepatitis B following vaccination. Option D - HBe Ag: Hepatitis B pre-core antigen typically suggests the infectivity of the virus; presence of this antigen suggests high infectivity, and the absence suggests low infectivity. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the influenza virus is false ?

options.B: Intranasal Live attenuated vaccine is used
options.C: 5-12 years is a High Risk Group

questions.explanation: of influenza typically include young children (especially those under 2 years), the elderly (65 years and older), pregnant women, individuals with underlying health conditions, and immunocompromised individuals. The age group of 5-12 years is generally considered to have a lower risk compared to these high-risk groups. Incorrect Options: Option A - Secondary Attack rate is 5-15%: The secondary attack rate refers to the proportion of susceptible individuals who develop the disease after being exposed to an infected individual. In the case of influenza, the secondary attack rate can vary depending on factors such as the specific strain, population density, and level of immunity. Generally, the secondary attack rate for influenza is estimated to be around 5 to 15%. Option B - Intranasal Live Attenuated Vaccine is used: Intranasal live attenuated vaccine, a trivalent vaccine H1N1 (A), H3N2 (A), type B is indicated for individuals with influenza infection, contraindicated in low immunity. Option D - Aquatic Birds act as Reservoir: Aquatic birds, particularly wild waterfowl, are considered the natural reservoir for influenza viruses. They can carry different strains of influenza viruses, including avian influenza viruses, without showing symptoms. These viruses can occasionally cross over to infect other species, including humans. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Choose the correct statement regarding CMV.

options.A: Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene
options.B: CMV can be cultured in vitro in any mammalian cell
options.C: Commonest manifestation of CMV associated disease is watery diarrhea
options.D: UL54 mutated CMV strains do not show cross resistance to Foscarnet

questions.explanation: Ganciclovir is a nucleoside DNA polymerase inhibitor an antiviral drug commonly used for the treatment of CMV infections. Resistance to ganciclovir can occur due to mutations in the UL97 and UL54 gene of CMV. Ganciclovir is converted by viral phosphotransferase encoded by the CMV UL97 gene to form ganciclovir triphosphate that inhibits CMV DNA polymerase. Mutations in the UL97 gene can result in reduced phosphorylation of ganciclovir, leading to decreased efficacy of the drug and the development of resistance. Incorrect Options: Option B - CMV can be cultured in vitro in any mammalian cell: Human fibroblasts are the most specific and ideal cell lines for the isolation of the cytomegalovirus. Option C - The commonest manifestation of CMV-associated disease is watery diarrhea: CMV is the most common infection associated with congenital defects. In Immunocompetent individuals, after transplantation, it causes mononucleosis-like disease, and in immunocompromised individuals (HIV/transplantation), it causes, most commonly, CMV retinitis. Option D - UL54 mutated CMV strains do not show cross-resistance to Foscarnet: UL54 refers to the DNA polymerase gene of CMV, which is the target of antiviral drugs like ganciclovir and foscarnet, and mutation in this gene can lead to resistance against ganciclovir, foscarnet, and cidofovir. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following organism is represented by the given form of replication ?
questions.explanation: Influenza virus. Influenza virus is an RNA virus that belongs to the Orthomyxoviridae family. Its replication process involves several distinct steps: Attachment: The spikes of hemagglutinin bind to sialic acid found on the surface of the host cell’s membrane. Entry: The virus enters the host cell by endocytosis, which involves the engulfment of the virus particle by the cell membrane and the formation of a vesicle called an endosome. Fusion: The viral envelope fuses with the endosomal membrane, and the M2 ion channel allows entry of H+ ions - H+ influx, resulting in uncoating and releasing the viral genetic material into the host cell's cytoplasm. Replication: The viral RNA serves as a template for the synthesis of new viral RNA segments (turning negative sense RNA into positive sense RNA), as well as viral proteins. The viral RNA polymerase, which is carried by the virus, is responsible for replicating and transcribing the viral RNA. Assembly: Newly synthesized viral RNA segments and proteins are assembled into new virus particles within the host cell. Budding: The assembled virus particles bud from the host cell's plasma membrane, acquiring an envelope derived from the host cell membrane. This process allows the virus to be released by neuraminidase and potentially infect other cells. Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A 6-months-old child presented with diarrhea and vomiting for three days. Which of the following enterotoxins is most likely responsible for the condition?
questions.explanation: with viral gastroenteritis, particularly caused by rotavirus infection. Rotavirus is a leading cause of severe diarrhea in infants and young children worldwide. Rotavirus produces several viral proteins, including enterotoxins, that contribute to the pathogenesis of gastroenteritis. Among these, NSP4 (Nonstructural Protein 4) is an enterotoxin primarily responsible for causing diarrhea by altering epithelial cell function and permeability. Structural proteins of Rotavirus: Structural protein: VP 1-4 , VP 6 , VP 7 . Non-structural protein: NSP 1-6 . Incorrect Options: Option B - NSP6: NSP6 is another nonstructural protein produced by rotavirus. However, it is not primarily associated with causing diarrhea or vomiting in infected individuals. Option C - VP3: VP3 is a structural protein of the rotavirus and is involved in the capping of the virus particle. Option D - VP7: VP7 is another structural protein of the rotavirus, known as the glycoprotein, that forms the capsid layer of the virus. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: The association of human herpesvirus 8 is observed in all of the following conditions except:
questions.explanation: Adult T-cell leukemia. Adult T-cell leukemia is caused by human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 (HTLV-1), a different virus belonging to the Retroviridae family. Human herpesvirus 8, also known as Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV), is a member of the herpesvirus family. It is primarily associated with certain malignancies and diseases, including: Kaposi sarcoma: A soft tissue sarcoma of vascular origin characterized by dark/violaceous plaques or nodules in immunocompromised individuals. Primary effusion lymphoma: A rare type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterized by the accumulation of lymphoma cells in body cavities, such as the pleural or peritoneal cavity. Castleman disease: A rare lymphoproliferative disorder characterized by enlarged lymph nodes. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which type of infection is more likely to occur following the transfusion of Solvent/Detergent (SD) plasma, given its ability to destroy lipid-enveloped viruses?
questions.explanation: with transfusion of solvent/detergent (SD) plasma. Solvent/detergent treatment is a method used to inactivate lipid-enveloped viruses in plasma products. It involves the use of organic solvents and detergents to disrupt the lipid envelope of viruses, rendering them non-infectious. This treatment method is effective against lipid-enveloped viruses. Non-enveloped DNA viruses - parvovirus, adenovirus and papovavirus Non-enveloped RNA viruses - picornavirus, reovirus, calicivirus, hepatitis A virus, and hepatitis E virus. Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect. These are enveloped viruses that can be destroyed by the solvent/detergent method. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Northern blotting is used for detection of which of the following ?
questions.explanation: by detecting and analyzing mRNA. It involves the separation of RNA molecules based on their size using gel electrophoresis, followed by their transfer onto a solid support membrane (usually nylon or nitrocellulose). The transferred RNA molecules are then immobilized on the membrane. To detect specific RNA molecules, the membrane is hybridized with a labeled nucleic acid probe that is complementary to the target RNA sequence of interest. The probe binds specifically to its complementary RNA sequence on the membrane, allowing the detection and visualization of the target RNA molecule. Incorrect Options: Option A - DNA: Southern blotting is used for the detection of DNA molecules. Option C - Proteins: Western blotting, immunohistochemistry, or enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) are commonly used for protein detection and analysis. Option D - None: Northern blotting is specifically used for the detection of RNA molecules. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Koplik spots are seen in?
questions.explanation: white-colored bumps on the erythematous base that appear in the mouth in the prodromal stage of measles. Prodromal phase of measles Fever - 1st manifestation around 10th day. 3 C's - Cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis. Pathognomonic feature - Kopliks spot near molar appears after 2 days of fever. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Koplik spots are not seen in these conditions. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following statements is accurate regarding antigenic drift ?

options.A: There is a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure
options.B: Causes a sudden increase in the number of cases
options.C: The new antigens formed are unrelated to the previous antigens
options.D: Antibodies to the predecessor viruses do not neutralize the new variants

questions.explanation: phenomenon that occurs in influenza viruses. It involves a gradual sequential change in the antigenic structure of the virus due to mutations in the genes that code for its surface proteins. These surface proteins, hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) are responsible for the recognition and binding of the virus to host cells and the release of newly formed virus particles from infected cells, respectively. The accumulation of these mutations in the HA and NA genes over time can lead to the emergence of new strains. Incorrect Options: Option B - Causes a sudden increase in the number of cases: This is inaccurate because antigenic drift is less likely to cause major epidemics and pandemics. Option C - The new antigens formed are unrelated to the previous antigens: The new antigens formed due to antigenic drift are related to the previous antigens, so they react with antisera to the predecessor virus strains to varying degrees. Option D - Antibodies to the predecessor viruses do not neutralize the new variants: Antibodies to the predecessor viruses still provide some degree of cross-protection against the new variants, but the degree of protection may vary depending on the degree of antigenic similarity between the old and new strains. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Parvo B19 associated with all except?

options.B: Transient aplastic crisis with hemolytic anemia

questions.explanation: immunocompromised is associated with Parvo B-19 virus not Aplastic anemia. Incorrect Options: Option A - Fever with petechial rash: Parvo B19 virus is associated with Erythema infectiosum which presents with macular erythematous rash present on the cheek Option B - Transient aplastic crisis with hemolytic anemia: Transient aplastic crisis with hemolytic anemia is associated with Parvo B-19 virus. Option D - Hydrops fetalis: Hydrops fetalis is associated with Parvo B-19 virus.

questions.question: A patient presents with painful vesicles in the genital region. Identify the lesion shown in the image and choose the correct diagnosis:
questions.explanation: are seen in HSV-2 infection. Incorrect Options: Option B - Chancroid: Chancroid causes painful ulcers but typically presents as a single, larger ulcer with ragged edges, not multiple vesicles. Option C - Syphilis: Syphilis causes painless genital ulcers. Option D - Candidiasis: Candidiasis does not cause painful vesicular lesions.

questions.question: A PLHIV came with multiple dog bites with a punctured wound. Choose the correctmanagement:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Local Treatment + RIG + Vaccine Explanation: For a PLHIV with category III dog bites (multiple deep wounds), the correct management is local treatment, Rabies Immune Globulin (RIG) , and the rabies vaccine. Management of Dog Bite: Category Exposure Type Management Category I Touching or feeding animals Licking of intact skin Ensure proper hygiene No treatment required Category II Nibbling on uncovered skin Minor scratches or abrasions without bleeding Immediate wound washing with soap and water Rabies vaccination: Unvaccinated: Days 0, 3, 7, and 14 Previously vaccinated: Booster doses on Days 0 and 3 No Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) required Category III Bites or scratches with bleeding Licks on broken skin Exposure to mucous membranes (mouth, eyes, nose) Immediate wound washing with soap and water, flush for at least 15 minutes. Suture: Do not suture the wound immediately, as it may spread the virus, instead delay it for 24 to 48 hours. Rabies vaccination : Unvaccinated: Full PEP series on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14 Previously vaccinated: Booster doses on Days 0 and 3 Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG): Equine immunoglobulin or ERIG Human rabies Immunoglobulin or HRIG Preferred (free from the danger of sensitisation, HIV and hepatitis viruses) Dose: – 40 IU / kg IM Started on Day 0 along with vaccination (can be given up to 7 days). 70% is given around the wound and, the rest is given distant from the wound. Required for unvaccinated individuals Not needed for previously vaccinated individuals Reference: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/358780496_Management_of_dog_bite

questions.question: A patient sample positive for Infectious Hepatitis B. Choose the correct marker for thiscondition.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) HBsAg + HBe Explanation: The correct marker for Infectious Hepatitis B is HBsAg + HBe , as HBsAg indicates active infection, and HBeAg signifies high infectivity. Stages and Associated Markers of Hepatitis B Virus (HBV): HBsAg HBeAg Anti-HBc Anti-HBs Anti-HBe Interpretation + + IgM - - Acute HBV infection Highly infectious + + IgG - - Chronic HBV infection, highly infectious + - IgG - -/+ Chronic HBV infection, low infectivity - - IgG -/+ -/+ Recovery - - IgM - - Window period - - - + - Post-vaccination Reference: Ananthanarayan and Panicker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 552 Apurba S Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 483 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK555945/

questions.question: A Tzanck smear prepared from a vesicle shows multinucleated giant cells. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) HSV Explanation: A Tzanck smear showing multinucleated giant cells is characteristic of Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections. Microscopic Features of the Herpes Virus: Herpes Simplex Virus: Tzanck smear: Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained 'ground-glass' chromatin ( Tzanck cells ). Formation of Lipschutz bodies (Cowdry type A). HHV 8 (human herpes virus type 8): Castleman disease: Onion skinning of lymphocytes and blood vessels, giving the appearance of “Lollipop follicles” . HIV (Option A) does not cause multinucleated giant cells on a Tzanck smear; it is diagnosed with serological tests (e.g., ELISA, Western blot) or PCR. HPV (Option C) is associated with koilocytes (perinuclear halos in epithelial cells), not multinucleated giant cells. EBV (Option D) is associated with Downey cells, which are atypical lymphocytes with a ballerina skirt appearance, seen in peripheral blood smears. Diagnosed using the Monospot test or serology, not a Tzanck smear.

questions.question: A patient is positive for HBsAg and anti-HBc IgM. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Acute hepatitis Explanation: A patient positive for HBsAg and anti-HBc IgM points toward Acute hepatitis B. Stages and Associated Markers of Hepatitis B Virus (HBV): HBsAg HBeAg Anti-HBc Anti-HBs Anti-HBe Interpretation + + IgM - - Acute HBV infection Highly infectious + + IgG - - Chronic HBV infection , highly infectious (Option B) + - IgG - -/+ Chronic HBV infection, low infectivity - - IgG -/+ -/+ Recovery (Option C) - - IgM - - Window period - - - + - Post-vaccination (Option D) Reference: Ananthanarayan and Panicker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 552 Apurba S Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 483 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK555945/

questions.question: Which of the following is false about influenza ?

options.A: Intranasal live attenuated vaccine is used
options.B: 5-12 years is a high risk group

questions.explanation: of influenza typically include young children (especially those under 2 years), the elderly (65 years and older), pregnant women, individuals with underlying health conditions, and immunocompromised individuals. The age group of 5-12 years is generally considered to have a lower risk compared to these high-risk groups. Incorrect Options: Option A - Intranasal Live attenuated vaccine is used: Intranasal live attenuated vaccine, a trivalent vaccine H1N1 (A), H3N2 (A), type B is indicated for individuals with influenza infection, contraindicated in low immunity. Option C - Aquatic birds act as reservoir: Aquatic birds, particularly wild waterfowl, are considered the natural reservoir for influenza viruses. They can carry different strains of influenza viruses, including avian influenza viruses, without showing symptoms. These viruses can occasionally cross over to infect other species, including humans. Option D - Secondary attack rate is 5-15%: The secondary attack rate refers to the proportion of susceptible individuals who develop the disease after being exposed to an infected individual. In the case of influenza, the secondary attack rate can vary depending on factors such as the specific strain, population density, and level of immunity. Generally, the secondary attack rate for influenza is estimated to be around 5 to 15%. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which type of virus is rubella ?
questions.explanation: enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA viruses. Rubella virus, also known as the German measles virus, belongs to the genus Rubivirus within the Togaviridae family. Other viruses included in Togavirus are: Chikungunya virus. Western equine encephalitis virus. Eastern equine encephalitis virus. Incorrect Options: Option A - Flavivirus: Flaviviruses are another family of RNA viruses and include viruses such as Japanese encephalitis, Yellow fever, Zika, Dengue, West Nile fever, and Hepatitis C. Option C - Paramyxovirus : Paramyxoviruses are yet another family of RNA viruses known for causing respiratory infections such as respiratory syncytial virus measles, mumps, parainfluenza, and Nipah. Option D. Orthomyxovirus : Orthomyxoviruses are a family of RNA viruses that include influenza viruses. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Identify the organism ?
questions.explanation: Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome . The main target site for Hantavirus is the lungs. Incorrect Options: Option A - Influenza Virus: Influenza is caused by Orthomyxovirus and is a single-stranded RNA virus. It has neuraminidase and hemagglutinin spike proteins. Option C - Adenovirus: It is a double-stranded DNA virus that is responsible for causing respiratory illness. Option D - None of the Above: This option cannot be the answer since the Hantavirus is an organism shown in the picture. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Antemortem diagnosis of rabies is made with?
questions.explanation: it requires specialized laboratory techniques. Antemortem diagnosis of rabies can be made by rabies antigen detection by performing a corneal impression smear, skin biopsy from the nape of the neck containing at least 10 hair follicles, and saliva. The viral antigens are present in these preparations and are examined for their presence using techniques like direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) testing. Incorrect Options: Option A - Rabies Virus Specific Antibodies: While the presence of rabies virus-specific antibodies can indicate a past infection or immune response, it is not a reliable method for antemortem diagnosis. Antibodies may take time to develop and may not be detectable during the early stages of infection. Option B - Inoculation in Cell Lines: Inoculation of samples in cell lines is a method used for viral isolation and growth but is not commonly used for antemortem diagnosis of rabies. It is a time-consuming process and requires specific laboratory facilities. Option C - Negri Bodies in Hippocampus: Negri bodies are characteristic microscopic inclusion bodies found in certain neurons of the central nervous system affected by rabies virus infection. However, their detection usually requires brain tissue examination postmortem (after death) and is not feasible for antemortem diagnosis. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following virus is from Herpes virus family?
questions.explanation: (HHV-4), is a member of the Herpesviridae family. It is associated with infectious mononucleosis (glandular fever) and is also linked to several other diseases, including certain cancers, such as Burkitt's lymphoma and nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Other members of Herpesviridae are Type Virus Associated Diseases HHV1 Herpes Simplex Virus 1 Oral herpes (cold sores), genital herpes, and encephalitis. HHV2 Herpes Simplex Virus 2 Genital herpes. HHV3 Herpes Zoster Virus Chickenpox and shingles. HHV4 Epstein–Barr virus Infectious mononucleosis, Burkitt's lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma. HHV5 Cytomegalovirus (largest member) Congenital infections, mononucleosis, organ transplant complications. HHV6 Human Herpesvirus 6 Roseola infantum, febrile illness HHV7 Human Herpesvirus 7 Febrile illness and a few cases of roseola infantum HHV8 Human Herpesvirus 8 Kaposi's sarcoma Incorrect Options: Option A - Rubella: Rubella is caused by the Rubella virus, which belongs to the Togaviridae family, not the Herpesviridae family. Option B - Measles: Measles, also known as rubeola, is caused by the Measles virus, which belongs to the Paramyxoviridae family. Option C - Rabies: Rabies is caused by the Rabies virus, which belongs to the Rhabdoviridae family. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Molluscum contagiosum is caused by?
questions.explanation: virus (MCV), which belongs to the Poxvirus family. MCV infects the skin and mucous membranes, resulting in the formation of small, flesh-colored, or pinkish bumps with a central indentation. These bumps are typically painless and may resolve on their own over time. Other members of poxvirus are the variola virus, causing smallpox, and the vaccinia virus, causing chicken pox. Incorrect Options: Option A - Adenovirus: Adenovirus is a group of human adenoviruses A to F that can cause respiratory infections, and conjunctivitis. Option B - Flavivirus: Flaviviruses are a family of viruses including dengue virus, zika virus, and yellow fever virus. Option C - Rubivirus: Rubivirus refers to the Rubella virus, which causes Rubella (German measles). Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: SSPE is a complication of?
questions.explanation: progressive neurological disorder that occurs as a late complication of measles virus infection. It occurs many years after measles, around 7- 13 years. But once it occurs, within 1-3 years, it becomes fatal. It manifests as progressive deterioration of motor and cognitive functions, focal/generalized seizures, myoclonus, ataxia, and visual disturbances. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect. SSPE is not a complication of these viruses. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which subtype of human papilloma virus has maximum chances of causing carcinoma cervix:
questions.explanation: HPV 16 and HPV 18, are known to have the highest association with the development of cervical carcinoma. Other high-risk human papillomaviruses associated with cervical carcinoma are HPV 31, 33, and 35. Incorrect Options: Option B - HPV 6 & 11: HPV 6 and HPV 11 are classified as low-risk subtypes and are commonly associated with condyloma acuminatum and laryngeal papillomatosis. Option C - HPV 31 & 32: HPV 31 is a high-risk subtype associated with cervical cancer, but HPV 32 is not associated with cervical carcinoma. Option D - HPV 1 & 2: HPV 1 and HPV 2 are low-risk subtypes associated with plantar warts/verruca and filiform warts. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Viral infection mimicking erythroblastosis fetalis is:
questions.explanation: “fifth disease” or erythema infectiosum. In some cases, Parvovirus B19 can lead to a transient aplastic crisis in a patient with an underlying hemolytic condition and hydrops fetalis, which mimics erythroblastosis fetalis. The virus infects erythroid progenitor cells, leading to temporary suppression of red blood cell production. Parvovirus B19 is, therefore, a viral infection that mimics erythroblastosis fetalis. Incorrect Options: Option A - HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus): HSV infection is primarily associated with oral or genital ulcers, and it does not typically mimic erythroblastosis fetalis. Option B - Epstein-Barr Virus : Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is the causative agent of infectious mononucleosis. Although EBV can cause abnormal liver function and anemia, it does not specifically mimic erythroblastosis fetalis. Option C - Picornavirus : Picornaviruses are a large family of viruses that include common viruses such as rhinoviruses and enteroviruses. While certain picornaviruses can cause mild respiratory or gastrointestinal symptoms, they do not mimic erythroblastosis fetalis. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Cowdry Type A inclusion s are seen in:
questions.explanation: inclusion bodies Negri bodies – rabies virus Paschen body – variola virus Guamieri bodies – vaccinia virus Bollinger bodies – fowlpox virus Molluscum bodies – molluscum contagiosum virus Perinuclear cytoplasmic body – reovirus Intranuclear Inclusion Bodies Cowdry type A inclusions Torres body – yellow fever virus Lipschutz body – herpes simplex virus Cowdry type B inclusions Poliovirus Adenovirus Intracytoplasmic and Intranuclear Inclusion Bodies Owl’s eye appearance – cytomegalovirus Measles virus Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation. Reference: Prepladder Notes
